comment._content: Seems a little harsh. The guy might be getting on a bit , but there's no need to be abusive.

comment.author: 29050464@N06
comment._content: Nice old slide. Added to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diplodocus#Discovery_and_species Thanks for posting these!

comment.author: 58446043@N04
comment._content: That is O.A. Peterson (Carnegie Museum) when he stopped by to visit Douglass (probably November, 1920 because so much of #355 is exposed). Peterson worked the Uintah Basin for several years and would stop by to visit (according to the letters of Douglass to Director Holland). The specimen behind Peterson is the Diplodocus (#355) excavated by the Smithsonian in 1924.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
Thank you, Ktneprac.  After receiving your comments, we went back to these slides to check the information on them.  I changed the date above to "undated".  The only information on the slide is "Diplodocus over 80ft in length."  No date or locality is provided for this slide.  The locality information was taken from the finding aid.  I also changed the locality to "possibly" Dinosaur National Monument Quarry.  We weren't able to find any further documentation for this image.  Would you mind sharing some of your sources with us?  In particular, we are interested in knowing how you were able to identify O. A. Peterson, the locality, and the specimen number.  Any additional information is appreciated.  In the meanwhile, I will ask staff from the Department of Paleobiology if they have any additional information.  Thank you again.

sonoe
Field Book Project
